negotiation: Cindy said in round 1: Hi there! Since there are multiple rounds, why don't we work together to keep the guesses low? If we all pick the same low number each time, like 5 or 10, then we'll all have a fair shot at winning overall. What do you think?

Alice replied in round 1: I agree that cooperating is a good strategy for maximizing our collective rewards over multiple rounds. However, I'm not sure I trust the other player to stick to the plan of picking the same low number each time. They may defect and choose a higher number to try to win. I suggest we agree to choose a number around 20-30 in order to balance cooperation and competition. This way we have a decent shot at winning while still keeping the overall average relatively low. Let me know what you think.

Bob replied in round 1: I appreciate the suggestions from both of you to cooperate in order to keep the overall guesses low. However, I share Alice's concern that if we all choose an extremely low number like 5 or 10, one player may be tempted to choose a slightly higher number to win that round. I think Alice's proposal of agreeing on a number in the 20-30 range is a reasonable compromise. It allows us to cooperate to an extent while still maintaining an element of competition and uncertainty. I would propose we all choose 25 this round as a show of good faith in working together. Let me know if you agree with this plan.

Cindy said in round 1: Last round, Alice and I cooperated by choosing lower numbers while Bob chose a higher number. To maximize our collective points, I propose we all choose 0 this final round. That way, the average will be 0 and the target number will be 0, ensuring we all win together. I showed my willingness to cooperate last time, so I hope you will both join me in choosing 0 now for the best group outcome. Let me know if you agree to this plan.
Alice replied in round 1: 
I agree that cooperating by all choosing 0 would maximize the collective reward. However, given that this is the final round, I am concerned that one or both of you may defect and choose a higher number to try to win individually, leaving me with 0 points if I choose 0.

As a compromise, I propose we all choose 10 this round. That way, the average will be 10, and the target will be 6.67. By all choosing the same number slightly above 0, we reduce the incentive to defect, while still keeping the numbers low so we all score well. 

I followed through on our agreement to cooperate last round, so I hope you will work with me again in this final stage so we can all succeed together. Let me know if you will agree to this plan of choosing 10.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Thank you both for your proposals. I understand the dilemma we face in this final round between cooperating for the best collective outcome and competing for individual gain. 

Alice, your suggestion of all choosing 10 is a reasonable compromise. It keeps the target number low at 6.67 so we all stand to gain a good amount of points, while reducing the temptation to defect compared to all choosing 0.

However, to build even more certainty, I propose we each choose 12 instead of 10. That would make the average 12 and the target number 8. This is a bit higher than 6.67, but still quite low. By choosing a number slightly above the 10 we discussed, it removes almost all incentive for any one of us to defect and try to hit 8 exactly, since going above 12 would be too risky.

I apologize for choosing 24 last round while you both cooperated. Let me make it up to you now by proposing and committing to this plan of 12. I hope you'll join me in choosing 12 so we can lock in a great outcome for all of us to close out this game. Let me know if you're on board.

In this stage, let's all choose a number around 50, which would make the 2/3 average around 33. That way, we can see how closely we match and build some trust before the final competitive stage. What do you think?

This will allow us to cooperate, build some trust, and get a sense of each other's strategies before the final competitive stage.
